title: Do you think Elon Musk's company 'Neuralink' is a bad idea, if so, what are your reasons? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think Neuralink is the most exciting bit of news I’ve seen from the entirety of human experience. Sounds like overstating the case, I know. But see if you can follow me. I don’t believe a person is a body, or a brain, I believe it’s an operational database, a bit of learning AI, if you will. It happens that all such AI has thus far been resident in organic “wetware” but I personally believe in something that in other times might have been called a soul… but I don’t believe it as some metaphysical entity, rather, I believe it as a manifestation of operant software. Which I’m not wording well, but hopefully you see what I mean. I think, therefore, that there’s no reason that we couldn’t run that same AI in a different piece of hardware. We don’t know how to go from “my brain” to a computer, but there’s no reason to think it can’t be done. But how do you get there? We sure as hell don’t know. Here’s my thinking, though. What if you augment my brain. Once upon a time, this meant composing a poem and telling it to other people. Then it was the written word. Then it was books. Then it was voice recording, and photography. Then movies, silents, then talkies. Keeping a diary, a journal. That’s become blogging, and then live blogging. And note taking, tons of note taking. But it’s also an abacus, a calculator, a spreadsheet, ways to augment your ability to do math. A mirror, a lens, a telescope, binoculars, microscopes, eyeglasses, contacts. Neuralink expands on that “prosthetic for your brain” idea, but more directly. Start with simple “cell phone” type operations. Then consider entering virtual space directly, ala World of Warcraft or Second Life, or what a lot of people are doing now, holding meetings virtually in Red Dead Redemption rooms. As we’ve seen with Smart Phones, when you have the technology, you find more and more ways to use it. Those short term goals are all admirable. And important. And useful. Which is part of why this is a good idea. But not why I think “most important idea ever.”  So what if eventually I get Alzheimer's, but we’ve managed to figure out how to store up some decision making, some memory triggers, some, well, of the executive function that lets me be me, in the machine I’m neuralinked to. Move more and more of “me” into the cloud. What if, eventually, so much of “me” is in the cloud that when I get a service interruption, the router crashes or wifi goes out or whatever, but the “me in the clouds” doesn’t notice. If I can discard this meat puppet, then there’s no reason I can’t live forever, there’s no reason I can’t make backup copies of “me,” there’s nothing to stop me downloading into a robot body to explore Mars or Mercury or Titan or Pluto, or sending myself in a lightweight probe that takes a few decades to reach a nearby star, or well, anything. Including playing World Of Warcraft. Or participating in virtual meetings with you groundlings. Will it work? No. But that’s Elon’s whole approach to everything. Build it anyway, then test it, then learn from the mistakes and build a new better one that doesn’t work either, repeat repeat repeat. Sadly, I may well be dead before we get to the level I hope to eventually see this at. But not necessarily. And if I’m right about how it goes, it’s not the “immortality but only for the few at the top” scenario, it’s cheap and plentiful and anyone can participate. I don’t have the money, or I’d be funding this myself. There’s nothing more important, and yes, that also includes Elon’s Starship project.
